sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Sparfloxacin (Zagam(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Bronchitis, chronic, Acute bacterial exacerbation: 400 mg ORALLY on day 1, then 200 mg ORALLY once a day for 10 days
  • Community acquired pneumonia: 400 mg ORALLY on day 1, then 200 mg ORALLY once a day for 10 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Sparfloxacin (Zagam(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Safety and efficacy in children under 18 years of age have not been established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: CrCl less than 50 mL/min, 400 mg on day 1, then 200 mg every other day for a total of 9 days (6 tablets total)

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Sparfloxacin (Zagam(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Bronchitis, chronic, Acute bacterial exacerbation
  • Community acquired pneumonia
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Sparfloxacin (Zagam(R)) is no longer available in the United States.
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Acute exacerbation
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Infectious disease of genitourinary system
  • Sinusitis
  • Urethritis
  • Urinary tract infectious disease

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to sparfloxacin products/quinolones
  • history of photosensitivity reactions
  • class Ia or class III antiarrhythmic agents, or other drugs that prolong the QTc interval
  • patients with known QTc prolongation
  • persons unable to avoid sun exposure

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• avoid exposure to direct and indirect sunlight during therapy and for 5 days after therapy; sunscreens are not effective
  • known or suspected CNS disorders

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Photosensitivity
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Indigestion, Nausea
  • Neurologic:Dizziness, Headache
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval, Torsades de pointes
  • Dermatologic:Phototoxicity
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (Severe) (rare)
  • Musculoskeletal:Traumatic or non-traumatic rupture of tendon (rare)
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Psychiatric:Drug-induced psychosis (rare)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Bactericidal; sparfloxacin acts intracellularly by inhibiting DNA gyrase . DNA gyrase is an essential bacterial enzyme that controls DNA topology and assists in DNA replication, repair, deactivation, and transcription .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • take with or without food
  • if given together, antacids containing aluminum or magnesium should be taken 4 h after the dose
  • if given together, sucralfate should be taken 4 h after the dose
  • if given together, didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution should be taken 4 h after the dose

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid exposure to direct/indirect sunlight and UV light sources such as sunlamps and tanning beds during therapy and for 5 days after therapy, as drug may cause phototoxicity (rash formation, dermatitis, or burning, redness, swelling, blistering, and itching of skin). Sunscreens will not provide adequate skin protection.
  • Patient should avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness.
  • This drug may cause diarrhea, dyspepsia, nausea, and headache.
  • Tell patient to immediately report arrhythmia or seizure activity.
  • Patient should maintain adequate hydration during therapy to prevent kidney problems.
  • Advise patient to take this drug at least 4 h before taking any vitamins/supplements, aluminum- or magnesium-containing antacids, sucralfate, or didanosine.
